Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
Youth at facility are being left in their rooms for long periods of time due to
understaffing. They are left in there for 3-4 hours during periods that should only be
for approximately 1 hour.
3

INVESTIGATION:
Complaint was received 06/07/21 and transferred to DCWL for investigation and
included the following allegations:
The children at the Calumet Center are being left in their rooms for long periods
of time due to understaffing. The children are being left in their rooms for 3-4
hours at a time when it should only be for about an hour during the day.
I attempted to interview the complainant on 06/09/21, but they did not respond.
I interviewed Manager 1 at the facility on 06/09/21. Manager 1 reported that the
staffing was in ratio as of this morning but shift change was just happening, so she
was not certain whether they had adequate coverage for the afternoon. Manager 1
said that there are times when they are understaffed and not in ratio. Manager 1 said
that when there are DHHS youth are on a pod the ratio is 1:5 and others are 1:9.
I met with Director 1 on 06/09/21 at the facility. Director 1 said that staffing is “tight”
at the facility. Director 1 reported the ratios to be 1:5 for DHHS youth and 1:8 for
others. Director 1 assisted with a tour of the facility to include several pods so that
ratio could be verified. One pod with DHHS youth was observed to have more than
five youth but only one staff.
I interviewed Youths B, C, and D at the facility on 06/09/21. All three youth were
from different pods. All three youths reported that the facility does not always have
enough staff. The youth said that they are sometimes locked in their rooms in
mornings and during shift change for longer times due to being short staffed. All
three youths said that the previous weekend was understaffed which resulted in the
youth remaining in their rooms for hours longer than they are supposed to be, and
also results in them missing some programming and level privileges (gym time,
staying up later). It was additionally reported by Youths C and D that one staff has
monitored two pods due to short staffing.
I spoke with the Chief Administrator at the facility and discussed the concerning
reports related to understaffing.
I discussed the staffing with the Chief Administrator, CEO, Director 1, Director 2, and
my Area Manager via a Teams conference call. The facility administration
acknowledged that the staffing is limited, that there have been times when ratio was
not met, and reported on their efforts to hire additional staff.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 06/17/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist. Staff
1 reported that the facility is staffed out of ratio at times. Staff 1 said that this occurs
at least two times per week. Staff 1 was asked what the ratio was and reported 1:9
for the county kids and did not know for the DHHS kids. Staff 1 reported that there
are days when one staff has to monitor more than 9 kids. Staff 1 said that youth are
4

usually let out of rooms after morning headcount, which is around 7:00am. Staff 1
did not know what time youth go to bed.
I interviewed the Supervisor on 06/17/21 at the facility, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. The Supervisor reported that the facility is “definitely understaffed” but
they have been in ratio during the Supervisor’s shifts.
During a 06/17/21 Placement Collaboration Unit call related to this allegation, it was
reported by multiple placing workers that their youth have reported being kept in
their locked rooms for hours, and especially on the weekends. One worker reported
that their youth reported not receiving programming due to staffing issues. Two
workers specified that facility staff acknowledged staffing issues directly to them.
Follow up emails were exchanged with one of the workers on the call. The worker
expanded on her report that one of her youth who is placed at the facility reported
that the youth are kept in the locked rooms for long five hour stretches on weekends
because of staffing issues.
I conducted unannounced visits to the facility on 06/09/21 and 06/17/21 and
interviewed a random sample of staff and youth during both visits. Multiple youth and
staff reported ongoing issues with understaffing and indicated that the facility is not
always able to meet ratio.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
o Calumet Residential Daily Census
o Facility policy Youth Supervision & Staffing. The policy notes staffing ratios
during ‘normal, waking hours, shall be no less than one worker to five
residents (1:5 for DHHS/JJ Youth); no less than one worker to eight residents
(1:8 for CMO/SJJS youth).’ Additionally, the policy notes that during sleeping
hours the ratio is one worker to ten residents.
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-
to-resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation as evidenced by multiple youth and
staff reports of understaffing leading to times when the facility is
not able to meet their ratio, as well as an observation of one pod
being out of ratio during a facility walk through.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It is advised that the administration review the ratio policy with
staff to ensure that all staff are aware of the correct numbers
since some staff reported incorrect ratio numbers.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
One youth is being denied medical treatment for pain.
INVESTIGATION:
Complaint was received 06/07/21 and transferred to DCWL for investigation and
included the following allegations:
An unknown female resident is being denied the right to see medical staff when
complaining of pain. It is not known what kind of pain she is experiencing.
I attempted to interview the complainant on 06/09/21, but they did not respond.
A second complaint was made regarding Youth A and was received on 06/11/21.
This complaint was assigned to the DHHS Specialist for joint investigation. The
allegations in the second complaint were:
Youth A (17) resides at Spectrum Human Services Calumet Center. Youth A has
been to the ER at Children Hospital in Detroit, MI three times in the past 10 days.
Youth A presents in the ER due to having Styrofoam and cotton balls in her
urethra. Youth A is supposed to be under a one-on-one protocol in the facility.
However, Youth A is being monitored via video while at the facility. Youth A gets
the Styrofoam and cotton balls while eating and taking medications. Youth A has
mental health concerns. Youth A is suicidal and is putting the objects in her
urethra in an attempt to harm herself.
6

I met with Director 1 at the facility on 06/09/21. Director 1 reported that Youth A has
been at the facility for over a year and is presently on suicide precautions due to her
emotional and behavioral issues, including putting objects in her urethra. She was
recently seen at the hospital, and this is not the first time this has occurred. Director
1 acknowledged that Youth A recently reported to him that she was having pain, and
he requested that she receive an exam.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 06/09/21. Youth A reported to have put five
pieces of foam cup in her urethra previously and had to have it removed at the
hospital. Youth A said she put cotton inside her today and noted that she was in pain
again. She reported that she does this to hurt herself and she wants to kill herself.
Youth A reported that has done this multiple times. Youth A indicated that she does
tell the staff, but per her interview, this does not always occur immediately. Youth A
stated that on one recent occasion she told Director 1 and was seen by the nurse
the next day and was sent to the doctor, where she had an operation to have the
item removed. Youth A reported that she does meet with a therapist at the facility but
did not feel it was helping her.
I met with the Chief Administrator (CA) on 06/09/21 at the facility and discussed the
concerns related to Youth A. The CA reported that she was aware of Youth A’s
status and her putting objects in her body. The CA reported that the facility has
replaced about a dozed mattresses due to Youth A picking the mattress until she
can get some string or cotton off of it. Youth A then self-harms with the material. Per
the CA, Youth A has done the same with the suicide vests provided to her and
Styrofoam cups. The CA said that she is currently seeking out indestructible cups
and plates to assist in keeping Youth A safe.
I met with Director 2 at the facility on 06/17/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Director 2 reported being aware of Youth A’s suicidal and self-harming behaviors
and that she puts objects inside her body. It was reported that the facility has
replaced 11 or so mattresses due to Youth A pulling threads out so that she can
access the cotton and put in inside her body. Youth A was also reported to have
pulled apart the facility suicide vests, grabs and hides anything she can, such as,
shampoo caps, paper, etc. That is why she has been kept on suicide precautions.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation is as follows:
 Youth A file review inclusive of medical documentation (both facility
documentation and outside documentation), safety plan, and related
documentation.
 Related facility Incident Reports dated 06/3/21, 06/08/21, 06/09/21, and
06/10/21.
 Hospital discharge paperwork, 06/30/2021. Indicated that Youth A continued
to insert various objects into her urethra, vagina, and nose while in hospital
care. This occurred while being supervised by one facility staff and one
hospital sitter, and some while mechanically restrained to the bed.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
ANALYSIS: The facility is compliant with this rule. Youth A reported that
when she advised staff at the facility that she inserted objects
into her body and that she was in pain, that she received
medical treatment. A record review also found that Youth A
received medical treatment several times for this issue.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Youth A has been to the hospital three times in ten days due to putting objects inside
her body. Youth A is on one-on-one supervision at the facility but is only being
monitored via camera.
INVESTIGATION:
A second complaint was made regarding Youth A and was received on 06/11/21.
This complaint was assigned to the DHHS Specialist for joint investigation. The
allegations in the second complaint were:
Youth A (17) resides at Spectrum Human Services Calumet Center. Youth A has
been to the ER at Children Hospital in Detroit, MI three times in the past 10 days.
Youth A presents in the ER due to having Styrofoam and cotton balls in her
urethra. Youth A is supposed to be under a one-on-one protocol in the facility.
However, Youth A is being monitored via video while at the facility. Youth A gets
the Styrofoam and cotton balls while eating and taking medications. Youth A has
mental health concerns. Youth A is suicidal and is putting the objects in her
urethra in an attempt to harm herself.
I met with Director 1 at the facility on 06/09/21 and he assisted with a tour of Youth
A’s pod and the control room. In the control room I observed a small monitor with a
camera view of Youth A in her bedroom.
I met with Director 2 at the facility on 06/17/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist. I
asked Director 2 about a request for a random sample of videos of staff checking on
Youth A to compare to the eyes-on checks forms. Director 2 reported that he
8

reviewed the requested videos of the staff checks and found that some staff were
only using the camera to check on Youth A instead of going to her room and
checking on her. Director 2 reported that staff know better and that they have been
trained and directed that the checks need to be done in person at the youth’s door.
I interviewed Manager 1 at the facility on 06/17/21 jointly with the DHHS Specialist. I
reviewed the suicide precautions logging forms for Youth A with Manager 1 and
asked about 06/04/21, when the log noted she was on duty but there was missing
documentation of eyes-on checks from 11:25am-11:55am. Manager 1 said that she
must have went to use the restroom and the person who relieved her did not fill in
the checks. Manager 1 did not recall who relieved her. Manger 1 reported that she
used to sit by Youth A’s door when she worked on that unit. Manager 1 also reported
that she and other staff do checks both in person and via the camera monitor in the
control room.
I interviewed Staff 1 on 06/17/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist at the facility. Staff
1 reported that she usually sits with Youth A for a while when she works on that pod.
Staff 1 reported that she visually does checks during her rounds on the pod. Staff 1
reported that she also does checks via the camera in the control room, but this is
usually when Youth A is asleep. Checks were reported to be done every five
minutes.
I interviewed the Supervisor on 06/17/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist, at the
facility. The Supervisor reported that she and staff do checks for Youth A both face
to face and via the camera in the control room.
Documentation reviewed during this investigation is as follows:
 Suicide precautions policy:
o III Procedure:
 A. 2. …Youth observation will be logged at intervals not to
exceed 5 minutes.
 E. Staff: 2. Using the level of precautions directed by the Facility
Manager on the Suicide Precautions Initial Level Form, staff
shall implement the level of suicide precautions as follows: b.
Monitoring of the youth will be logged using the Suicide
Precautions Form at 5-minute intervals.
 Suicide precautions logging forms for Youth A, 06/04/21-06/10/21. The
following was observed:
o 06/04/21-Missing eyes-on checks from 11:25am-11:55am.
o 06/06/21-Missing eyes-on checks from 9:05am-10:55am.
9

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4161 Seclusion rooms; policies and procedures.
An institution approved to use a seclusion room shall
establish and follow written policies and procedures
specifying its use. The policy shall include, at a minimum,
all of the following provisions:
(e) Staff shall observe the resident at intervals of 15
minutes or less and shall record the observation in a
seclusion room log. Video surveillance shall not be the only
means of observation.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule evidenced by the missing
documentation of checks on the youth. The facility policy calls
for 5-minute checks and multiple daily logs did not document all
checks were completed. Additionally, the staff reported not
always doing face to face checks and stated that they use the
camera for checking on the youth. This was also reported by the
Director, who said that he reviewed video of staff doing checks
and found that some staff were checking Youth A via video only
and not going over to her room.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The facility documentation did not contain all of the required hourly supervisory
approvals for ongoing seclusion due to self-harming/suicidal behaviors.
INVESTIGATION:
Documentation reviewed during this investigation is as follows:
 Suicide precautions policy:
o III Procedure:
 F. Shift Supervisor: 3. The shift supervisor shall review the
status of each youth on suicide precautions in person, on an
hourly basis, indicating this review by initialing in the
supervisor’s block on the Suicide Precautions Logging Form. 4.
New Suicide Precautions Logging Forms shall be started at
12:00am of each day and be given to the Youth Worker
monitoring the youth on suicide precautions. The previous day’s
form will be collected, copied, and filed. The original log will be
filed with the Facility Manager and a copy will be immediately
submitted to the Center Director.
10

 J. Center Director: The Center Director shall monitor the daily
status of youth under suicide precautions and ensure that
appropriate steps have been taken to provide for the safety of
the at-risk youth.
 Suicide precautions logging forms for Youth A, 06/04/21-06/10/21. The
following was observed:
o 06/04/21-Missing supervisory approval from 9:40pm-11:55pm.
o 06/05/21-Missing supervisory approval from 9:00pm-11:55pm.
o 06/06/21-Missing supervisory approval from 6:00am-11:55am.
o 06/07/21-Missing supervisory approval from 3:00pm-11:55pm.
o 06/08/21-Missing supervisory approval from 11:00pm-11:55pm.
o 06/10/21-Missing supervisory approval from 11:00pm-11:55pm.
o One form contained no name, date, or other information. Eyes-on
checks were documented, but no supervisory approval was done at all
from 12:00pm-11:55pm.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4162 Seclusion rooms; administrative oversight.
(4) For each instance in which a resident remains in the
room for more than 2 hours, the log shall contain hourly
supervisory approval and the reasons for continued use.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation as hourly supervisory approval did not
occur for the ongoing seclusion. The facility policy notes that
supervisors will do hourly in-person checks and document the
checks by initialing the form. This was observed not to have
always occurred in the observation forms reviewed as noted
above. Also, the facility policy notes the Center Director receives
copies of the forms and is responsible to monitor the process,
however, the forms were not addressed as incomplete, and the
Director did not know that staff were using video only to monitor
the youth in some cases.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting a timely
and acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violation.
